description.narrative: Insatsen "Stärka den colombianska polismyndighetens kapacitet att bidra till en hållbar fred" (2018-2020) bidrar till colombiansk polis övergång från militär- till civil polis. Insatsen genomförs av svensk polis tillsammans med colombiansk polis och syftar till att stärka den colombianska polisen i att nå hållbar fred med fokus på tre områden: förebyggande, polisutbildning samt förvaltning och ledarskap. Projektets specifika mål är: (1) Utveckla polisens förebyggande arbete (2) Uppdatera modellen för polisutbildning och (3) jämställdhet i polisens interna arbete. Övergripande frågor såsom multidimensionell fattigdom, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, konfliktkänslighet samt miljö- och naturresurser är integrerade i de olika projektkomponenterna och resultatramverket.

Stöd för kapacitetsutveckling av colombiansk polis, genom den svenska Polismyndigheten. Insatsen är en fortsättning på det samarbete mellan colombiansk polis och den svenska Polismyndigheten som har pågått sedan 2013. Projektet har utvecklats i samarbete mellan de båda myndigheterna och bidrar till reformen av Colombias säkerhetssektor, med fokus på ökad medborgerlig tillit och tillgång till polisens tjänster, samt med det övergripande målet att förbereda colombiansk polis för en framtida övergång från militär till civil myndighet. Genom insatsen har svensk polis en rådgivande funktion till sin colombianska motsvarighet, inom områdena polisutbildning, brottsförebyggande arbete och jämställdhet. Ingen vidareförmedling av medel sker till colombiansk polis inom ramarna för denna insats.

Support for capacity development of Colombian police, through the Swedish Police Authority. The contribution is a continuation of the cooperation between the Colombian police and the Swedish Police Authority that has been ongoing since 2013. The project has been developed in cooperation between the two authorities and contributes to the reform of Colombia's security sector, focusing on increased civic trust and access to police services, with the overall aim of preparing Colombian police for a future transition from a military to civilian authority. Through the contribution, the Swedish police have an advisory function to their Colombian counterpart, in the areas of police training, crime prevention and gender equality. No forwarding of funds to colombian police takes place within the framework of this contribution.

description.narrative: This is the first year of the second phase of the Swedish police cooperation project. This phase builds on the strengths and weakness of the first phase and was developed together with the Colombian police. It is Sida's assessment that the report is well written summarizing what the police cooperation has achieved during the year including the main challenges. The strength of the whole project is the confidence gained by the Swedish Police to work at the centre of PNC (Colombian National Police) reform process on a selected strategic issues that were introduced already in the first project phase. With the change of leadership of all Colombian police directors following the presidential election, confidence, trust and ownership had to be build up again that caused some delays in project implementation. The ownership of the project from PNC is currently assessed to be strong. Of the three project components, the one on prevention has progressed the most and according to plan. This is followed by the component on education. The third component on leadership had to be changed to gender equality due to lack of political will from PNC (Colombian National Police) that is fundamental. This changed was communicated and approved by the Embassy. Within a relatively short period of time the project managed to introduce and build support for the model of preventive work among the PNC leadership as well as creating favourable conditions for activates 2019 including the elaboration of a pilot plan for preventive work. Within the education component an analysis of the curriculum was carried out as well as continuing education of selected police officers in the areas of "case methods", "tactic system", prevention and intra-familiar gender based violence. The gender component managed to make an analysis of the current knowledge of the theme within PNC as well as the realization of basic gender training carried out by gender experts from the Swedish police. However, due to the fact that this component was introduced late in the reporting period it has a low outcome of results in relation to the objectives. Despite the progress, some major challenges remain that will be taken up in dialogue: 1) Maintain the political will of PNC (also when leadership of PNC changes) for a successful implementation of the project. 2) Effective application of the knowledge gained. 3) Continuity of the project given the volatile staff-turn over of Colombian police and change of project leader from the Swedish police.
